docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans of Norwalk, Conn., is talking with at least one hospital chain about changing the way it pays for services for Medicare patients, an official for North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System said yesterday. North Shore, which operates 13 hospitals, said it is talking with Oxford about becoming one of the health maintenance organization's major providers. Medicare is the Federal government program that pays for medical care for the elderly and disabled.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Chairman of a new commission studying the future of Medicare called on Congress today to defer action this year on President Clinton's proposal to open Medicare to people 55 to 64 years old. The recommendation, by Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, dims the prospects for Congressional approval of the plan before this year's midterm elections. Leading Republicans had already expressed opposition to the proposal.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two administrators of a midtown medical clinic were charged with mail fraud yesterday and accused in a scheme to perform plastic surgery on patients without a license in which insurance companies were billed at least $350,000, according to a complaint unsealed in Federal District Court in Manhattan. One of the administrators, Sonia LaFontaine, 43, of Manhattan, was arrested yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The agents also seized records from the clinic, LaFontaine-Rish Medical Associates, which offers reconstructive and cosmetic surgery at 315 West 57th Street.

Vowing to make child care an overriding priority, these unions, representing almost a million workers, want Albany to subsidize 50,000 more child-care slots, to build more day-care centers and to train child-care workers better.

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans made the remarkable admission last week that its losses during the last months of last year exceeded the total of all its previous profits. Oxford's performance is more embarrassing than even its stunning losses indicate. Its management did not have a clue how much money it was paying out to doctors or collecting from members. In fact, Oxford has been losing money for some time, but no one knew. Late last year, its bookkeepers caught up to a sorry reality. Now Oxford is off to a new start, with an infusion of $350 million from an outside investor and a new chief executive, Norman Payson, who replaces the company's visionary but managerially challenged founder, Stephen Wiggins. The new Oxford starts out with a strong customer base and a large roster of high-quality doctors and hospitals. It also inherits an inchoate reform that Mr. Wiggins designed for the future but which makes even more sense now that his old business strategy has come unglued. If managed well, Oxford can prosper.

docs.lead_paragraph: TWO years ago, Boris Ogursky was working for the catering arm of Lufthansa, the German airline, when he saw the future and made a bet. The German Government was selling off the last bits of the airline to investors, and Lufthansa management was trying to introduce employees to the idea of having a stake in the company's success. In place of a pay raise, employees could choose between a onetime cash payout and an equivalent amount of stock.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE TAXPAYER Relief Act of 1997 not only added complexities to the tax code -- like multiple rates and holding periods for capital gains. But it also has confused some taxpayers who are looking for breaks now that do not take effect until 1998 or later. ''It's amazing the number of people who think the 1997 law's changes took effect immediately,'' said John H. Gardner, senior manager in the Washington national tax office of KPMG Peat Marwick. ''They say, 'Where is that child credit I'm supposed to get? I've got a bad form.' ''
